items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe says he is confident higher interest rates are having their desired impact on the economy, but flags future increases may be necessary to tame inflation. Follow live.

title.children: Lowe 'confident' high interest rates are working but more hikes may be needed, NAB boss faces questions

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market rose for the second day in a row in what's been a quiet day for markets as investors await the latest US consumer inflation figures which are out tonight. The ASX 200 index put on 0.4 per cent after coming off its earlier highs. Most sectors rose driven by energy stocks and miners after an overnight rise in commodity prices on hopes of more stimulus from China. More possible Chinese stimulus and a weaker greenback saw the Australian dollar jump above 67 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ends higher

children.content: The Australian share market rose for the second day in a row in what's been a quiet day for markets as investors await the latest US consumer inflation figures which are out tonight.
The ASX 200 index put on 0.4 per cent after coming off its earlier highs.
Most sectors rose driven by energy stocks and miners after an overnight rise in commodity prices on hopes of more stimulus from China.
More possible Chinese stimulus and a weaker greenback saw the Australian dollar jump above 67 US cents.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As you've been hearing, the Reserve Bank has announced major changes after the federal government accepted the recommendations of the RBA Review. These include: Eight meetings a year instead of 11 starting from February 2024 A press conference by the RBA governor after each meeting Longer meetings Policy decision issued by the RBA board not just the governor Quarterly statements on monetary policy issued after meetings in February, May, August and November Commonwealth Bank economist Ryan Felsman has welcomed the changes to the operation of the RBA. "An increase in transparency, communications and detail around policy decisions and the outlook will be helpful to better understand and forecast monetary policy and the broader Australian economy." AMP chief economist Shane Oliver thinks fewer meetings make sense "although by meeting less they may sometimes have to move by more". Economist and former prime ministerial adviser Stephen Koukoulas says the bulk of the changes were decided when the RBA review was released earlier this year. Here's an explanation of the changes from business reporter Gareth Hutchens.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA reaction

featuredLink.title: Reserve Bank board to only meet eight times a year as part of big changes, says governor Philip Lowe

children.content: As you've been hearing, the Reserve Bank has announced major changes after the federal government accepted the recommendations of the RBA Review.
These include:
Eight meetings a year instead of 11 starting from February 2024
A press conference by the RBA governor after each meeting
Longer meetings
Policy decision issued by the RBA board not just the governor
Quarterly statements on monetary policy issued after meetings in February, May, August and November
Commonwealth Bank economist Ryan Felsman has welcomed the changes to the operation of the RBA.
"An increase in transparency, communications and detail around policy decisions and the outlook will be helpful to better understand and forecast monetary policy and the broader Australian economy."
AMP chief economist Shane Oliver thinks fewer meetings make sense "although by meeting less they may sometimes have to move by more".
Economist and former prime ministerial adviser Stephen Koukoulas says the bulk of the changes were decided when the RBA review was released earlier this year.
Here's an explanation of the changes from business reporter Gareth Hutchens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ has increased interest rates on fixed-term mortgages for both owner occupiers and investors by up to 0.55 percentage points. That brings ANZ's two-year fixed-term mortgage from 5.99 per cent to 6.54 per cent. Macquarie has also raised its fixed rates by 0.36 percentage points, with more hikes than cuts to fixed-rate loans over the last month, according to RateCity. RateCity says the big four banks' lowest fixed-rate mortgages are mainly above 6 per cent, with just two fixed rates under 6 per cent. RateCity research director Sally Tindall: "ANZ's fixed-rate hikes comes amid a distinct lack of competition in the fixed rate market and heat from funding pressure." Ms Tindall says bank customers should look at credit unions and mutuals which have fixed rates well under 6 per cent. Just 5 per cent of new and refinanced loans are fixed, compared to nearly half in July 2021 when interest rates were at record lows.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ ditches fixed rates under 6 per cent

children.content: ANZ has increased interest rates on fixed-term mortgages for both owner occupiers and investors by up to 0.55 percentage points.
That brings ANZ's two-year fixed-term mortgage from 5.99 per cent to 6.54 per cent.
Macquarie has also raised its fixed rates by 0.36 percentage points, with more hikes than cuts to fixed-rate loans over the last month, according to RateCity.

props.alt: Table showing fixed rate mortgages for big four banks

children.content: Big four fixed rates
(RateCity)
RateCity says the big four banks' lowest fixed-rate mortgages are mainly above 6 per cent, with just two fixed rates under 6 per cent.
RateCity research director Sally Tindall:
"ANZ's fixed-rate hikes comes amid a distinct lack of competition in the fixed rate market and heat from funding pressure."
Ms Tindall says bank customers should look at credit unions and mutuals which have fixed rates well under 6 per cent.
Just 5 per cent of new and refinanced loans are fixed, compared to nearly half in July 2021 when interest rates were at record lows.
